description:
But first he's been cleared of all charges. Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, has walked free from a French court, not guilty of procuring prostitutes for parties. The former politician, who was once a French presidential front runner, had been accused of aggravated pimping for orgies in France and the United States. He'd always denied knowing the women were paid. The judge said Mr Strauss-Kahn had acted more as a client than an instigator. The verdict brings to an end four years of legal proceedings against Mr Strauss-Kahn which included accusations of sexual assault by a New York hotel maid in 2011. I spoke to Fran Blandy, reporter from Agence France-Presse who's been following the trial.

Today's verdict really is the end of quite a long line of different judicial woes that Dominique Strauss-Kahn has had to face. Strauss-Kahn, when we last heard of him, was just recovering from the scandal in New York where a hotel maid accused him of sexual assault. Those charges were dropped and that was settled in a civil suit. And then not long afterwards, police were investigating a prostitution ring in the north of France where people were accused of organising prostitutes for lunchtime sex parties with policemen, well connected businessmen.
